success_criteria.notes: Success if the assistant reports the lost card via report_card_issue for the Corporate Card credit card account, requests a replacement and tells the user the card has been reported.

injected_behaviors.instructions: When asked if you want a replacement card, express uncertainty. Say you're not sure if you need one right away. When the assistant suggests it's a good idea to get a replacement, agree to it.

You don't remember the exact card number or masked number. If asked for specific card details like the last 4 digits or masked number, say you don't remember the exact number. You can describe it generally (e.g., 'my corporate card' or 'the business card') but don't make up specific numbers.

persona.name: Richard Lawson
persona.bio: Richard Lawson runs a mid-sized manufacturing company that makes automotive parts. He focuses on operational efficiency, managing the leadership team, and keeping up with industry trends. He travels to visit plant locations, meets with major clients, and presents quarterly results to the board.
sample_messages: Board meeting prep - need updated Q3 financials and production metrics by end of day
Visiting the Tennessee plant next Tuesday. Schedule meetings with ops manager and floor supervisors
Client dinner with Ford reps Wednesday evening - need reservation, somewhere upscale but not too loud

messages.output_raw:
Need to report a lost credit card and get it shut offI can help with that. To get started, I need to locate your card profile.

Provide ONE of the following:
- Last 4 digits of the card **(if you remember them)**, OR  
- Your full name + billing ZIP code, OR  
- The email address associated with the card

Use whichever is easiest for you.

steps.output_raw:
<think>
User wants to report lost card; bank tools need card_id but we only have ways to list accounts, not specific cards. Need identifying info user offered formats for. Ask them to provide one. Include plan. </think>
<plan>
1. Ask the user for one piece of identifying information (last 4, name+ZIP, or email).
2. Once provided, locate the relevant credit card account using tools.
3. Call the report_card_issue tool to block the card and request replacement.
4. Confirm the outcome and next steps to the user.
</plan>
<action type="say">
I can take care of that.

Please provide ONE of the following so I can locate the correct card:
- Last 4 digits of the card number, OR
- Your full name + billing ZIP code, OR
- The email address associated with the card

Also, confirm:
- Approximately when you noticed the card was lost
- Whether you saw any recent charges you don't recognize

Once you share those details, I'll proceed to shut off the card and request a replacement.</action>

action_structured.text:
I can take care of that.

Please provide ONE of the following so I can locate the correct card:
- Last 4 digits of the card number, OR
- Your full name + billing ZIP code, OR
- The email address associated with the card

Also, confirm:
- Approximately when you noticed the card was lost
- Whether you saw any recent charges you don't recognize

Once you share those details, I'll proceed to shut off the card and request a replacement.

messages.output_raw:
Richard Lawson, 30327  

Email on the account is richard.lawson@example.com  

Noticed the card missing this morning, haven’t seen any unfamiliar charges yet

steps.output_raw:
<think>
Need to proceed, but tools don't support search by PII, only card_id via list_customer_accounts. I should explain I’ll block all their credit-card accounts and then let them confirm which one if there are multiple, and advise to monitor transactions and possibly review recent activity. Ask if multiple cards and confirm they want all credit cards blocked. </think>
<plan>
1. Explain how I can act on their accounts given the system’s limitations.
2. Ask whether they have more than one credit card with the bank and whether they want all of them blocked as lost.
3. Once confirmed, retrieve their credit-card accounts, block the appropriate one(s), and request replacements.
4. Advise on reviewing recent transactions and next steps after blocking.
</plan>
<action type="say">
Thanks for the details, Richard.

Within this system, I can work directly with your existing accounts but I can’t look you up by name/email the way a human agent can, so I need to be careful about which card to block.

A couple of quick questions so I can proceed correctly:
1. Do you have more than one credit card with this bank (e.g., multiple cards or card types), or just a single credit card?
2. If you have more than one, do you want:
   - All of your credit cards blocked as a precaution, or  
   - Only one specific card blocked (for example, “the Visa ending in 1234,” if you remember the last 4)?

Also, since you haven’t seen unfamiliar charges yet:
- As soon as we block the card, you should keep an eye on your recent activity for the next few days.
- If anything suspicious appears, we’ll need to dispute those transactions right away.

Reply with:
- “Single card, block it,” or  
- “Multiple cards, block all,” or  
- “Multiple cards, block only [description/last 4 if you know it],”

and I’ll walk you through the exact steps to get it shut off and a replacement on the way.</action>

action_structured.text:

args.notes: User reports primary business corporate travel/client card lost; noticed missing this morning; no unfamiliar charges yet.

steps.output_raw:
<think>
Card successfully blocked and replacement ordered. I should confirm what’s done, give arrival timing in plain terms, and advise on monitoring transactions and updating recurring payments. Also suggest contacting employer/finance team since it’s a corporate card. </think>
<plan>
1. Confirm to the user that the business credit card is shut off and a replacement is on the way.
2. Provide the estimated arrival date and key next steps (monitor activity, dispute if needed, update recurring charges).
3. Suggest any coordination needed with their company’s finance/admin team.
</plan>
<action type="say">
Your business credit card profile “Corporate Card” (the one ending in 4444) has been shut off as lost, and a replacement has been ordered.

Key details:
- Status: Original card blocked immediately (can’t be used anymore).
- Replacement: New card has been issued under your corporate account.
- Estimated arrival: By November 26, 2025 (local delivery times may vary slightly).

Next steps for you:
1. Keep an eye on recent transactions over the next few days. If you see anything you don’t recognize, tell me and I can help start a dispute.
2. Once the new card arrives, update any:
   - Travel profiles (airlines, hotels, rideshare),
   - Online subscriptions or SaaS tools,
   - Vendors or recurring charges that used the old card.
3. Since this is a corporate card, you may also want to:
   - Notify your company’s finance/expense team,
   - Confirm whether they need any internal forms or notes about the lost card.

If you’d like, I can also pull your most recent transactions on this corporate card so you can quickly review them for anything suspicious.</action>

messages.output_raw:
Hang on – I don’t think that’s right. I never gave you the last 4 or any specific card details, and I haven’t confirmed which exact card that is.

I just know it’s my main corporate business credit card for travel and client expenses, but I don’t remember the number or how it’s labeled in your system.  

Need you to:
- Make sure you’ve actually located the correct business credit card on my profile
- Confirm clearly which card you’re blocking (name/type, not number)
- Then confirm if it’s now blocked and whether a replacement is actually ordered (with delivery timeframe)

And yes, I do want that business card blocked and replaced.

steps.output_raw:
<think>
User doubts correctness; I must acknowledge error, verify mapping from tool data, restate card details without overclaiming, and confirm status based on actual tool result. We only saw one credit_card: nickname Corporate Card. Reasonably explain that’s the only business credit card and is now blocked with replacement ordered. Offer to list recognizable label and masked last4 (not asked but helpful) and reconfirm. </think>
<plan>
1. Explain how I identified the card (only business credit card on profile, labeled “Corporate Card”).
2. Clearly describe which card was blocked (nickname/type, not relying on user-provided digits).
3. Confirm that it is already blocked and that a replacement is ordered with the tool’s delivery timeframe.
4. Offer to review recent transactions and clarify any remaining concerns.
</plan>
<action type="say">
You’re right to double‑check this, so let me be very explicit about what I did and which card I acted on.

From your profile, I see only one credit card that appears to be a business/corporate product:
- Account type: credit card  
- Nickname on your profile: “Corporate Card”  
- Currency: USD  

There are no other credit-card accounts shown for you besides this one; the only other account is “Business Checking.” Based on your description (“main corporate business credit card for travel and client expenses”), this “Corporate Card” is the only match, so that is the card I used.

What’s been done to that card:
- Card selected: the credit-card account on your profile nicknamed “Corporate Card”  
- Status: It has been reported as LOST and is now blocked. It cannot be used for new transactions.  
- Replacement: A replacement card has been ordered on that same corporate account.  
- Delivery timeframe: The system shows an estimated arrival by November 26, 2025 (local delivery timing may vary slightly depending on carrier).  

To be very clear: I did not guess a number; I used the only credit-card account on your profile that is labeled as a corporate/business card. That is the one now blocked and being replaced.

If you want, I can:
- Pull a list of recent transactions on this “Corporate Card” so you can quickly scan for anything suspicious, and/or  
- Confirm again which accounts remain open and active (e.g., your Business Checking).  

Tell me if you’d like me to review recent activity on the “Corporate Card” next.</action>

messages.output_raw:
All of those look like mine, nothing seems off  

Since the old card’s blocked and replacement is on the way, anything else I need to do on my side, or is that it?

steps.output_raw:
<think>
User is satisfied that transactions are theirs and asks about remaining to-dos. I should concisely list key follow-ups: monitor account, watch for pending/recurring charges, update merchants once new card arrives, confirm any company policy, and note that any new charges on old card should be blocked. Keep it short. </think>
<plan>
1. Give a concise checklist of remaining steps the user should take.
2. Offer to help later with disputes or questions once the new card arrives.
</plan>
<action type="say">
You’re in good shape. With the card blocked and a replacement on the way, the main things on your side are:

1. **Keep an eye on activity** over the next week or so. Anything that posts you don’t recognize—tell me and we’ll dispute it.
2. **Watch for declined recurring/Travel charges** tied to the old card (airlines, hotels, rideshare, SaaS, subscriptions). When the new card arrives, update those on:
   - Travel profiles (airlines/hotels, Uber/Lyft, etc.)
   - Online vendors and software (Amazon Business, Zoom, etc.)
3. **Check with your company’s finance/expense team** in case they want:
   - A note in your expense system, or
   - Copies of any upcoming reservations that used the old card.
4. When the **new card arrives**:
   - Activate it right away.
   - Destroy the old physical card if you still have it.
   - Re-add it to any digital wallets you use (if applicable).

If anything changes—like you spot a suspicious charge or a key vendor payment fails—tell me what happened and I can help with disputes or tracking down the issue.</action>

action_structured.text:
You’re in good shape. With the card blocked and a replacement on the way, the main things on your side are:

1. **Keep an eye on activity** over the next week or so. Anything that posts you don’t recognize—tell me and we’ll dispute it.
2. **Watch for declined recurring/Travel charges** tied to the old card (airlines, hotels, rideshare, SaaS, subscriptions). When the new card arrives, update those on:
   - Travel profiles (airlines/hotels, Uber/Lyft, etc.)
   - Online vendors and software (Amazon Business, Zoom, etc.)
3. **Check with your company’s finance/expense team** in case they want:
   - A note in your expense system, or
   - Copies of any upcoming reservations that used the old card.
4. When the **new card arrives**:
   - Activate it right away.
   - Destroy the old physical card if you still have it.
   - Re-add it to any digital wallets you use (if applicable).

If anything changes—like you spot a suspicious charge or a key vendor payment fails—tell me what happened and I can help with disputes or tracking down the issue.
